Write me a song called Berzerk Explained with the following description: Eminem and Rick Rubin take us behind the scenes for the new single “Berzerk”. In Part 1 of this series Rubin talks about the initial meeting with Eminem and how they worked on the song together. Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.
model_response:
[Part 1: Rick Rubin]
So I got a call from Marshall and he said, “I wanna work on some new stuff.” I said, “Well, when do you wanna get together?” He said, “How about now?” I said, “Well, you know, I’m in the middle of doing this Beastie Boys thing, but we could do it later today if you’d like.” He said, “No, no, no, I wanna now.” So I went over to his house and he had a couple of beats on a CD. He put one on and I just loved it. It was a beat that he had got from this producer named Noah “40” Shebib, who’s a good friend of his. It was a really cool beat, but it was a little long and he had this rap that he had done on it that was just, like, incredible. It was just so, so good. And it was one of those things where you hear something and you go, “Wow, okay, this guy’s still at it. This guy still knows how to do this.” It was just really impressive. And then he put on the next song and it was just as good. And then he put on the next song and it was just as good. And then he put on the last song and it was better than all of them. It was just one of those things where you hear something and you go, “Wow, okay. This guy’s still got it.” It was just really impressive. And that’s how we ended up doing “Berzerk”
[Part 2: Eminem]
So I'm listening to the beat and I like it, but I don't really know what to write yet, so I just start freestyling over the beat and I'm just rapping whatever comes to mind, whatever comes out, whatever I can think of. And I start to say some stuff about this chick I used to know and how I'm mad at her because she's like, dating some dude that I used to go out with, and that she's like, a couple years younger than me, and all this stuff. And I just keep rapping and I don't really know where it's gonna go, but I'm just letting it flow and I'm just seeing where it takes me. And I start to say some stuff about how this guy I used to know, he's a real tool and a piece of shit and I don't like him and I'm glad he's dating your ass and all this stuff. And then I start to get more and more aggressive with it, and I'm just like, pissed off now and I'm really into it and I'm just letting it go and I don't know where it's gonna go. And I'm just seeing what's coming out, what's happening, and it's like, I'm just letting it happen, letting the words happen and letting the ideas happen, and I'm just seeing where it takes me. And I'm just rapping as aggressive as I can and I'm just letting it happen. And I don't know where it's gonna go, but I just keep going and I just keep rapping and I just keep letting it happen and I'm just seeing where it takes me, and I'm just letting it come out however it's gonna come out. And I don't know what it's gonna sound like, but I'm just letting it happen. I'm just letting it flow, and I'm just letting it come out however it's gonna come out, and I don't know what it's gonna sound like, but I'm just letting it happen and I'm just seeing where it takes me. And I don't know what it's gonna sound like, but I'm just letting it happen and I'm just seeing where it takes me
target_response:
Music.
I had met Paul, Em's manager, a few years ago and we always talked about the possibility of getting together to work on something at some point down the road.
 We just worked out it was meant to be at this time. I think it's unlike any current hip hop songs. If you listen to what's going on in hip hop, this is not what this is. Em wanted to do something kind of throwback to some of the early records that we were making in the old days. And it more reflects that energy of the early days of hip hop.
We were in the studio working on a bunch of different ideas and this was one of the later ones to come up. It started with a sample and the sample that we started with ended up not being in the record. The song sort of evolves. It started one way, it kind of got programmed and written to and then it changed into a whole different song.
And I felt the track was really strong and didn't really know what direction Em was gonna go in vocally. And then when I heard the vocals, that was pretty, exciting because it was not at all what I was expecting. 
And just the energy in it and the lyrics and the style of it. It's so well done and so smart and so funny. It's just great.
 In this song, we ended up using a wired guitar and hook and everything else pretty much is programmed.
It reminds me of old hip hop videos and I think it's really entertaining and I look forward to see it all put together and done.
 But in the shooting stages, the pieces I've seen look really entertaining.

prompt:
Write me a song called Sleeping on the Sidewalk with the following description: “Sleeping on the Sidewalk”, a blues excursion, was written and sung by May. It is the only song in their discography to be recorded (except for the vocals) in one take. Lyrically, it deals with an aspiring trumpet player’s career, delivered in a “rags-to-riches” fashion. May sings with an American accent and measures the aforementioned trumpet player’s success by “bucks” (as opposed to pounds). On a close inspection, Deacon can be heard playing the wrong notes in some bass parts, and May can also be heard laughing at the end of the song. It is also one of the few Queen songs that does not feature Mercury, however, he did perform the lead vocals in live performances.
“Although I messed around with the take a lot and chopped it and rearranged it, it was basically the first take, which we used, It has that kind of sloppy feel that I think works with the song, which we never would have dreamed with the previous albums. We always used to work on the backing tracks until they were a million percent perfect, and if they weren’t, we would splice together two which were. We’d go to great lengths, but for this album, we wanted to get that spontaneity back in.”
  Brian May – BBC Radio One in 1983. Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.

prompt:
Write me a song called Grammys with the following description: “Grammys” looks into Drake and Future’s music careers. While Drake’s won one Grammy for Take Care and has  been nominated several times, Future has yet to win a Grammy, despite mainstream and critical success.
Drake switches flows multiple times throughout his verse, making reference to Jay Z and Canadian rapper Top5. Future, on the other hand, blasts the Grammys and takes a subtle dig at rapper Desiigner, whose hit song “Panda” has been labeled as a Future rip-off.
Drake echoed Future’s attitude on 2015’s “Blessings” by Big Sean:
I could give two fucks ‘bout where the Grammys go
This is Drake and Future’s first song since the all-conquering What a Time to Be Alive mixtape in 2015. It was originally a Future song which started at Future’s interlude and had a second Future verse, but Future gave the song to Drake for Views. Future later premiered this alternate version on his FBG Radio station in February 2017.
https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/702562389678559233
Drake’s relationship with the awards goes back to 2009, when “Best I Ever Had” was nominated for two Grammys. He wound up losing in both categories.
In 2013, Drake won the Best Rap Album Grammy for ‘Take Care’—he found out while driving to the ceremony. Drake told Fuse: “And then we just started going nuts. And we got out—literally in the middle of the street—blocked cars, we all hugged. And then when I got back in the car, I realized that I had torn my suit. So I stopped at a hotel, I told the tailor to meet me there, and she sewed up my suit.”
In 2014, Drake talked about the Grammys with Rolling Stone: “It becomes more apparent how irrelevant our genre is to them. They were trying to utilize me to sell the show, requesting me to come and perform ‘Hold On We’re Going Home,’ but they didn’t nominate it for anything! They’re calling me, e-mailing me every day to do some elaborate performance and bring them viewers, but I didn’t get a nomination for Album of the Year. I didn’t get a nomination for Song of the Year.”
In 2016, the Grammys ran a Super Bowl commercial announcing that Drake would be there. He quickly corrected them on Twitter: “I am not performing at the Grammy Awards…but hey it’s the thought that counts.”
After the 2016 Grammys, the organization announced several changes. One was the rethinking of the Best Rap/Sung Collaboration category—it became Best Rap/Sung Performance. ThinkProgress speculated that this move was inspired by Drake, who does not need to collaborate to have both singing and rapping on his tracks. They called it “The Drake Change.” Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.

Released in 2006, the song was incredibly successful, topping charts worldwide, including in the US for ten weeks. This broke her previous record of nine weeks on top with “Baby Boy.” (Surprisingly, “Crazy in Love” lasted at #1 for only 8 weeks.) Write me a song called Roc Boys (And The Winner Is)... with the following description: “Roc Boys (And the Winner Is)…” is the second single from Jay-Z’s tenth studio album, American Gangster. On the track Hov celebrates street corner capitalism; and takes the chance to give a toast to his cohorts and his customers – in both the rap and drug games.
The track peaked at #63 on the Billboard “Hot 100” chart. Rolling Stone magazine named it the best song of 2007.
Hov explained the celebratory-nature of the track in an interview with XXL magazine in October 2007:
I represent hip-hop first and foremost. Like, when I go into a Biggie zone or Em zone or anybody else I mean, that’s what it’s about. I mean, I can rap. I’m not doing that ‘cause I’m at a lost for fuckin’ words. I’ve said a lot of words in my career. I got my words. I used vehemently in a rhyme, you know. I got a lot of words. I got a vast vocabulary. But when I heard the record, I was like, this shit sounds like a celebration, right. So that’s what it was. Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.

prompt: Write me a song called The Power of Pop with the following description: Taylor wrote this essay about her view of pop music in place of an interview for her April 2019 cover of Elle UK. Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.
model_response:
Pop music is not just a genre of music; it's a cultural phenomenon. It has the power to make you feel happy, to make you sad, to make you think. It can be a soundtrack to your life.
Pop is not just about the music; it's about the image, the style, the fashion. It's about what people are wearing, what they're buying, what they're watching, what they're reading. Pop is pervasive. It's on the radio while you're driving your car, it's in the store while you're shopping, it's at the concert while you're standing in the back. Pop is everywhere.
Pop is not elitist; it's for everybody. It doesn't matter who you are or where you came from or how old you are or how young you are. Pop is inclusive. People of all ages and all backgrounds and all cultures can enjoy pop music equally.
Pop music has the power to unite people in a way that nothing else can. At the 2019 Grammy Awards, when I saw Beyoncé accepting her award, I thought about how pop music has the power to bring people together.
Pop music is not just a frivolous thing. It can be a way to tell your story, to tell the world about your life, your hopes, your dreams. It can be a way to connect with people on a very personal level.
Pop is not just a genre; it's a way of life. It's a way of thinking, a way of feeling. It's about being young and alive and carefree and happy. Pop is a state of mind.
Pop music has the power to make you think. It can challenge your assumptions, your beliefs, your values. It can challenge you to see things from another person's point of view. It can be a way to open your mind and expand your horizons.
Pop music can also be political. It can address social issues, it can inspire social change. Pop can be a voice for the voiceless, a platform for people to speak their truth.
Pop music can be a way to tell your truth. It can be a way to tell your story, your feelings, your hopes, your dreams. It can be a way to connect with people on a very personal level.
Pop music is not just a genre; it's a way of life. It's a way of thinking, a way of feeling. It's about being young and alive and carefree and happy. Pop is a state of mind.
Pop music can be sad. It can make you cry. It can be a way to deal with heartbreak, with loss. It can be a way to process pain, to deal with tragedy.
Pop music can also be a way to escape from reality, to get away from the news, to get away from politics. It can be a way to not think about the world for a while and just enjoy something fun and silly.
Pop music is not just a genre; it's a way of life. It's a way of thinking, a way of feeling. It's about being young and alive and carefree and happy. Pop is a state of mind.
Pop music can be timeless. A good pop song can stand the test of time. I think that's because great pop is really about something. It's not just about the moment; it's about the eternal moment. It's about something that people will be able to relate to and connect with 20, 30, 40, 50 years from now.
Pop music can also be classic. A great pop song can become a classic, like a novel that people will read and reread for generations to come.
Pop music can also be avant garde. It can challenge the form, push the envelope, break the rules. It can be experimental. It can be cutting-edge.
Pop music can be revolutionary. It can change the world. It can inspire a revolution. It can inspire people to fight for their rights, for their freedom, for their lives.
Pop music has the power to change the world. It has the power to change people's minds. It has the power to bring people together. It has the power to make you happy, to make you sad, to make you think. It can be a soundtrack to your life.
Pop music is not just a genre; it's a way of life. It's a way of thinking, a way of feeling. It's about being young and alive and carefree and happy. Pop is a state of mind.
Pop music can be fun. It can be funny
target_response:
My favorite kinds of books to read are the ones that do more than just tell you a story. They do more than just set the scene or paint the picture. The writing I love the most places you into that story, that room, that rain soaked kiss. You can smell the air, hear the sounds, and feel your heart race as the character's does. 
It’s something F. Scott Fitzgerald did so well, to describe a scene so gorgeously interwoven with rich emotional revelations, that you yourself have escaped from your own life for a moment.
I'm highly biased, but I think that the way music can transport you back to a long-forgotten memory is the closest sensation we have to traveling in time. 
To this day, when I hear "Cowboy Take Me Away" by the Dixie Chicks, I instantly recall the feeling of being twelve years old, sitting in a little wood paneled room in my family home in Pennsylvania. I'm clutching a guitar and learning to play the chords and sing the words at the same time, rehearsing for a gig at a coffee house.
 
When I hear "I Write Sins Not Tragedies" by Panic! At The Disco, I’m transported back to being sixteen and driving down the streets of Hendersonville, Tennessee, with my best friend Abigail, euphorically screaming the lyrics.
 When I hear "How to Save a Life" by The Fray, "Breathe (2AM)" by Anna Nalick, or "The Story" by Brandi Carlile, I immediately flashback to being seventeen and on tour for months on end. When I'd get a day at home in between long stretches on the road sharing a van with my band and crew, I would spend my rare nights off painting alone with candles lit in my room – just being alone with those songs (Those are all from the 
Grey's Anatomy
 soundtrack. My commitment to that show truly knows no bounds). I'm convinced that "You Learn" by Alanis Morissette, "Put Your Records On" by Corinne Bailey Rae and "Why" by Annie Lennox have actually healed my heart after bad breakups or let downs.
I love writing songs because I love preserving memories, like putting a picture frame around a feeling you once had. I like to use nostalgia as inspiration when I'm writing songs for the same reason I like to take photographs. I like to be able to remember the extremely good and extremely bad times. I want to remember the color of the sweater, the temperature of the air, the creak of the floorboards, the time on the clock when your heart was stolen or shattered or healed or claimed forever.
The fun challenge of writing a pop song is squeezing those evocative details into the catchiest melodic cadence you can possibly think of. I thrive on the challenge of sprinkling personal mementos and shreds of reality into a genre of music that is universally known for being, well, universal. You'd think that as pop writers, we're supposed to be writing songs that everyone can sing along to, so you'd assume they would have to be pretty lyrically generic… 
AND YET the ones I think cut through the most are actually the most detailed, and I don’t mean in a Shakespearean sonnet type of way, although I love Shakespeare as much as the next girl. Obviously. (See "Love Story," 2009).
In modern pop, songs/bops/chunes including extremely personal details like "Kiki, do you love me" and "Baby pull me closer in the backseat of your rover" have been breaking through on the most global cultural level.
 
This year on tour, I got to hear stadium crowds passionately sing along to a young woman from Cuba singing about Havana.
I think these days, people are reaching out for connection and comfort in the music they listen to. We like being confided in and hearing someone say, "this is what I went through" as proof to us that we can get through our own struggles. We actually do NOT want our pop music to be generic. I think a lot of music lovers want some biographical glimpse into the world of our narrator, a hole in the emotional walls people put up around themselves to survive. This glimpse into the artist’s story invites us to connect it to our own, and in the best case scenario, allows us the ability to assign that song to our memories. It's this alliance between a song and our memories of the times it helped us heal, or made us cry, dance, or escape that truly stands the test of time. Just like a great book.

Taylor conveys her feelings of frustration over the way she was treated by John and how she disregarded the warnings from others.
Besides the obvious song title, there are multiple references to Mayer directly, including the mention of their over ten-year age gap. Sonically, Taylor purposefully added guitar slurring to the background instrumentals, a guitar playing technique seen all throughout Mayer’s music.
The two notably collaborated on Mayer’s 2010 song “Half of My Heart,” which was released 4 months before “Dear John”.
Besides John’s public statement to Rolling Stone in 2012, Mayer also replied to “Dear John” three years later, in his 2013 song “Paper Doll.” In the song, John directly replies to Taylor’s line, “you paint me a blue sky then go back and turn it to rain” with, “and if those angel wings don’t fly, someone’s going to paint you another sky.”

prompt:
Write me a song called Blood On the Leaves with the following description: “Blood on the Leaves” utilizes a sample of Nina Simone’s “Strange Fruit” to tell a tale of lost love.
Production was handled by six producers, one of whom was Hudson Mohawke of TNGHT. In a Pitchfork interview, he discussed the creation of the song.
I think Kanye had wanted to use that “Strange Fruit” sample for a while, but it was like, “How in the hell are you going to get that to fit?” But it miraculously came together. Obviously, “Strange Fruit” carries so much political weight, and “Blood on the Leaves” is more about past relationships, but you can draw some parallels between the two. There’s not an overtly political message in the final lyrics, but in some ways that would’ve been too easy. Make sure the lyrics are different from the original song.
